content.description:
A king line with a committing deadpointÂ to a sloping lip and a scary mantle. A punt on the topout could eject you 20 feet down a hill. Don't punt.

 Stand start at the right side of the face on the pedestal. Climb up and leftwards on seams and edges utilizing a lot of core and some heel hooks. Fire for the lip and hold the swing with everything you've got before matching and beached whaling your way up unless you're a Galloway.
content.location: This problem sits on top of a hill and overlooks the Lone Wolf Area.

content.description:
Climb up onto the decent sized boulder underneath The Big-Swirly. Reach up to an incut 3 finger right-hand sidepull and grab a small left-hand micro-crimp pinch and compress the two. Figure out where you want your feet and bust a huge jump start to the large shelf five feet up and over your head. Hold on tight and take an incredible swing over a nasty landing. Match the large shelf with some slight difficulty and figure out where the next good hold is. Continue up directly using good holds and press it out at the top above and exponentially downgrading landing. 

 An impressive and bold boulder problem. The next question is simply, how do you enjoy your tea?
content.protection: At least 6 pads. Don't punt the top.
content.location: This bold problem is located on the left-side of the steep overhanging East-face of the boulder.

content.description: This is an impressively steep and proud boulder with a terrifying landing. This boulder sits on top of a pedestal boulder which allows for some fun cams and some impressive foot-cuts on a 55-degree wall. This boulder seems to have the potential for 5 or 6 possible lines and perhaps a few variations.
